The Chiefs of Staff reported as follows :-bomber command.Egypt andLibya.GreeceNavalOperations-..Shipping Losses.MilitaryOperations.Egypt.Night of December 10. Only 7 enemy machines had been over this country. No interceptions had been made.Night of December 11. A large number of aircraft had been over this country. Birmingham had been the main enemy objective.After about 1 a.m. the enemy concentration had seemed to fall off,and bombs had been dropped indiscriminately. Two interceptionshad been made. It was believed that at least one enemy machine hadbeen destroyed.Night of December 10. We had sent out 67 machines to attackvarious targets in Germany.Night of December 11. Forty-three machines had attackedMannheim and aerodromes in North-West France. Our losses amounted to 2 machines.The air casualties in the Libyan offensive so far had been asfollows : Our own 5 machines (2 crews safe).Enemy 17 certain.8 probable.Italian air reinforcements had been hampered by our raid onCastel Benito the previous Saturday night, when 50 machines hadbeen damaged or destroyed.December 10. Our bombers had attacked Valona and had obtained a direct hit on an enemy transport.Units from the Mediterranean Fleet were co-operating in the libyan operations.The Dutch sloop Van Kingsbergen had intercepted the GermanS.S. Rhein of 6,031 tons west of Florida Strait, which had been seton fire. It was not yet known whether she could be saved.The Rotorua (British, 10,890 tons) had been todpedoed on theprevious day 100 miles North-west of St. Kilda. Tugs had beensent to her assistance.The Cardita, which had been in the same convoy as the Rotorua,had opened fire on a U-boat, and had claimed a direct hit.Only 2 ships out of Convoy H.X.91 now remained to be accounted for.Sidi Barrani had been captured, although pockets of the enemy were still holding out at Point 90, some 9 miles to the south-east.The 4th Armoured Brigade were making for Sollum, and were nowwest of Buq Buq. An enemy Tank Group and a portion of a Black-shirt Division withdrawing to Sollum had been heavily engaged bythe Royal Air Force, who had inflicted severe casualties. Over7,000 prisoners had reached Matruh, and there were large numbersstill in the forward area. Large fires had been started at Sollum andat Halfaya, some 5 miles to he south.The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.[22021] Foreign 2. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs reported asInformation. follows : A telegram (No. 1201) from Madrid reported thatM. Dupuy, the Canadian Charge d'Affaires, had seen marshal petain and Admiral Darlan. Admiral Darlan had said thatthe French Government would resist German pressure to attack the de Gaulle colonies, anyway until February, and possiblylonger. He added that there was now no question of Germanybeing granted the use of French Metropolitan or African bases.If the German pressure became irresistible, they would inviteus in time to take them over. He was confident that the french ships would have time to leave the Metropolitan harbours and,if not, they would scuttle themselves. M. Dupuy had addedthat Marshal Petain had agreed with these views.^pain. The latter had seen no objection to the courseReference- o:^ ao^on proposed, and said that he would take the same line asW i\'I (40) 301st ProPosed by the Government in all public statements.Conclusions, It was agreed that action on the line proposed should be1 Minute 8.) j ustified on the ground of economic necessity; and that the strongestargument in favour of its adoption was that it afforded the best way of breaking the present impasse.The Prime Minister said that, before taking action on the linesfavoured by the War Cabinet at their last meeting, he thought itwould be wise to consult President Roosevelt. He proposed to telegraph to him in the course of the next few days. ProvidedPresident Roosevelt did not react strongly against the proposal,there would be nothing to prevent action being taken. (40) 300thConclusions,Minute 5.)6. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theMinister for Aircraft Production (W.P. (G.) (40) 318' (Revise))recommending for approval proposals which had been agreed as theresult of discussion between the three Supply Ministers andMr. Purvis.The War Cabinet also had before them an unnumbered telegram dated the 12th December from Mr. Mackenzie King to the PrimeMinister.In discussion the following amendments to W.P. (G.) (40) 318(Revise) were adopted : Paragraphs (1) and (4). For " British-North AmericaSupply Council " read " British Supply Council in north america."After discussion, the War Cabinet agreed on the followingcourse of action ; (a) It should be explained that the Government were perfectlyready that a statement on this matter should be made inthe House of Lords in open sesssion, on the lines of thestatement made by the Prime Minister in the House ofCommons on the 10th December.(b) In the Governments considered view, however, this matter could not be effectively debated without reference tosecret matters, which must not be revealed to the enemy.Again, public debate would be likely to stir up con-troversy between the Royal Navy and the Royal AirForce.(c) If, therefore, after hearing the Government statement, theHouse of Lords still desired to debate the matter, theGovernment adhered to their view that this should bedone in secret session.(d) The Lord Chancellor was invited to see Lord Trenchardand explain the matter to him on the basis of (a) to (e)above.(e) If the House of Lords debated this matter in secret session,it was essential that the Government spokesmen shouldbe provided with material for their speeches which would justify the Government's contention that the matter was not one which could properly have been debated in public session. Paragraph (1). The phrase " under the general aegis and authority of the Ambassador '' should be deleted. The phrase" in harmony with the Ambassador " should be inserted after" The Council " in paragraph 3.Paragraph (3). For " all political issues concerningSupply " substitute " all issues of policy concerning Supply."The following additional points were made in discussion : (a) It was the intention of paragraph (7) of W.P. (G.) (40) 318(Revise) that the relevant papers of the Supply Com-mittee in London should be circulated to all the interested Departments. There would be a standingsecretariat under the direction of Sir Andrew Duncan.On this understanding, it was agreed that the arrange-ments in paragraph (7) safeguarded the position of thenon-Supply Departments.(&) Some discussion took place on the relationship between theBritish Supply Council and the War Office Mission whichthe War Office were about to send to the United States.The War Office Mission would remain directly responsible to the War Office, and would not be subordinated to theBritish Supply Council on technical matters. On theother hand, the Head of the Military Mission would actin consultation with Mr. Purvis, and under his general guidance. For example, Mr. Purvis would advise him as to the personages and Departments in the UnitedStates with whom he should establish relations.The War Cabinet- .(1) Approved the arrangements proposed in W.P. (G.) (40) 318(Revise), subject to the amendments set out above.(2) Agreed that those arrangements should come into operation from the date of Mr. Purvis's arrival in the UnitedStates on return from this country.(3) Invited the Foreign Secretary to communicate the new arrangements to His Majesty's Ambassador in washington.(4) Invited the Departments concerned to inform their Missionsof the new arrangements, and to concert the terms and date of despatch of these communications with theForeign Secretary.Air Raids. ; 7. The Minister of Home Security said that the main enemy casualties and attack on the previous night had taken place against Birmingham,Damage. where many fires had been reported, all of which were now under(Previous control. Some 12- factories, 8 schools, 5 churches, and 2 cinemasReference: had been damaged. A secondary attack had taken place againstW.M. (40) 302nd Cheltenham. The railway lines to the south had been damagedConclusions, outside Birmingham and the line to South Wales and the West of minute 3.) England had been damaged outside Cheltenham.There had been a few incidents in London, including one atSouthgate and one in Page Street, Westminster.The casualties had been : London: 28 killed, 17 reported injured to date.Birmingham: 41 killed, 298 injux^ed.Elsewhere: 21 killed, 107 injured.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,December 12, 1940.
